div1.p: Hench discusses details of the upcoming Lazear memorial ceremony.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Ralph Cooper Hutchison, October 21, 1940
div1.p:
Wink Craig is delighted to be able to come, and quite
understood the matter of his not being a delegate. I would
appreciate it greatly if you would let me pay for his football
ticket and dinner, etc., but let it appear that he is a guest
of the college, or at least of yours and mine. John Garvin
may come up with him from Pittsburgh. Of this, I am not ab-
solutely sure. They will arrive Saturday morning, as Wink
cannot get there Friday night. Could one or two tickets be
reserved for them, and perhaps they could take care of mother
at her table, with or without Mary. Are women allowed to go
to the evening banquet?

Two weeks ago I had a letter from Miss Elizabeth
Peabody, of the Department of Biology, of Wilson College,
Chambersburg, Pa. Her father was head of the Biology Department
of some large school in New York City and later associated with
the Museum of Natural History there. Almost single-handed, he
successfully waged a campaign which resulted in life annuities,
Congressional medals, and an honor roll, granted to the yellow
fever experimenters. Her father has helped me, and she wonders
whether your exercises are open “to interested bacteriologists.
Some of my students might be able to attend.” I have written
her suggesting that she write to Miss Hough, telling if any
are coming. If any of the above needs answering, I leave here
Wednesday, and will arrive at mother's Thursday morning. Mother,
Mary and I, possibly also Mr. Kissinger (if he joins us in
Pittsburgh) will leave Pittsburgh on the 12:15 train from Union
Station and will taxi to our hotel in Washington. For Heaven's
sake, don't bother about us: We will see you at the reception.
div1.closer: Sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
